titleStmt.title: To Reify or Not to Reify: A Linked Open Data Question

sourceDesc.bibl: Title of work, Ontologies for Linked Data in the Humanities, 2019) prepared for the Ontologies for Linked Dara in the Humanities Workshop at the DH2019 conference in Utrecht, sponsored by the Alliance for the Digital Humanities Linked Open Data Special Interest Group, and organized by Kim Martin and Susan Brown with committee members Johanna Drucker, Ryan Shaw, Joseph T. Tennis, and Jasmine Drudge-Willson….

abstract.p: This paper considers reification as a component of Linked Open Data (LOD) practices. Reification allows one using LOD to move beyond binary relations and to treat a property or triple as an entity in itself about which one may in turn make statements (W3C), as a means of addressing one of the major limitations of the subject–predicate/property–object structure of LOD triples. It provides the ability to make statements in a granular way about, for instance, the provenance, certainty, or context of a LOD assertion. However, there are also significant disadvantages associated with reification, such as a large increase in the overall numbers of triples as well as the conversion of properties to classes, with a consequent reduction in the logical operations that can be performed on the data (Hernandez 2015; Stevens 2010). Nevertheless, reification is used in many LOD contexts, including by Wikidata (Erxleben 2014), a collaborative linked open data repository which is being increasingly used by researchers within the humanities, libraries, archives, and museums, and in whose aggregation functionalities it plays an important role.

We illustrate with examples of several reification strategies, outline the pros and cons of reification, and describe the dilemmas regarding whether to use reification within the OWL ontology of the Canadian Writing Research Collaboratory (CWRC 2018) and CWRC’s associated data extraction processes. The CWRC ontology team initially avoided reification due to wariness about making the data structure more complex and multiplying triples. However, as the team grappled with the need properly to contextualize materials, and adopted the Web Annotation data model to do so, it became apparent that reification would offer a number of advantages. However, we eventually went with a schema-regulated structure that builds on the Web Annotation Data model.

bibl.title: To Reify or Not to Reify: A Linked Open Data Question

div.p: Reification allows one using Linked Open Data to move beyond binary relations and to treat a property or triple as an entity in itself about which one may in turn make statements (W3C), as a means of addressing one of the major limitations of the subject–predicate/property–object structure of LOD triples. It provides the ability to make statements in a granular way about, for instance, the provenance, certainty, or context of a LOD assertion. Typically, we think of LOD in terms of triples that are relatively straight-forward and easy-to-comprehend subject-predicate object assertions; however, such a structure can be confining when it comes to conveying the complexity and relatedness of humanities discourse in LOD form. Triples are designed by definition to stand on their own: a triples is an assertion without qualification, that floats out into the world, connected with everything else associated with its entities and properties, such as class relationships, or relationships to other properties defined in the ontology, but unconnected to any specific context.

Reification provides a means of saying things about the things we are talking about, such as where the assertion came from, who said it, when, and what evidence or sources it draws upon. Whether to reify our assertions in order to be able to provide this kind of content confronted our work on a LOD strategy for the Canadian Writing Research Collaboratory (CWRC), a platform for engaging in cultural research online, such as digital editing, creating thematic collections, bibliography, born digital argumentation, prosopography, and so on. CWRC uses LOD to increase the findability and interoperability of its data. The dilemma outlined here emerged from the work of the CWRC ontology team, as it strove to figure out a form of Web Ontology Language (OWL)-compliant LOD that will serve the manifold purposes of scholars using the platform. The one which the CWRC team is working with first, to develop our ontology and our methods, is largely being generated from the Orlando Project’s XML encoding of feminist literary history, though we’re consulting with other projects as we go, given that we want the ontology to be as broadly useful as possible.

Reification in a nutshell:
allows one using LOD to move beyond binary relations
property or triple can be treated as an entity
one can make statements about this new entity

Reification allows one using LOD to move beyond binary relations and to treat a property or triple as an entity in itself about which one may in turn make statements (W3C). Take a simple triple such as the following:

This is a binary relation, a relationship between 2 things. But what if you want to say more about L.E.L.’s cause of death. Or what if there are two possible causes of death? In this case there are actually 3. There is no way with simple triples to indicate that this cause of death is uncertain. hasCause of Death is here a generic property so you cannot say that all causes of death are uncertain. What is required to provide such additional information is n-ary rather than binary relations.

To represent n-ary relations, you don’t necessarily need full reification. One can instead make certain properties of the graph instances of a more generic property, by defining the relationship as an individual data instance rather than a generic class, e.g. L.E.L’s causeOfdeath, so one can say that her death has a cause and that this cause is debatable. Such individual data instances can be typed to indicate that they are all causes of death. However, although this solves certain problems, such as that of certainty, it still precludes discussion of the statement as a whole. That requires full reification.

In full reification, the subject, the predicate, and the object all become instances. Here is the triple above represented as reified triple:
Here all individuals, that is all instances of reification, become instances of rdf:Statement, and they all gain URIs or identifier so one can say things “about” them.

Advantages to this type of reification include the following:
Reified triples provide the ability to make statements in a granular way, for instance, the provenance, certainty, or context of a LOD assertion
Content can be explicitly modelled as assertions or statements, rather than as reflections of “fact” (or factoids) which is important to those in the humanities
Addresses one of the major limitations of the subject–predicate/property–object structure of LOD triples
Meets OWL specifications
Retains the simple RDF triple structure
Reification is certainly used, and routinely recommended, if in passing, in textbooks LOD even as late as 2010/11
One context increasingly relevant to DH in which reification seems to be used is in Wikidata. Wikidata is collaborative linked open data repository which is being increasingly used by researchers within the humanities, and by libraries, archives, and museums. It’s become an important clearinghouse and aggregator for our field. (However, read on! There's a catch!)

There are, however, also clear disadvantages to such reification:
Reification multiplies data, producing a large increase in the overall numbers of triples: 4 times more than one had initially, creating a big increase in storage demands. CWRC’s first partial tranche of data generated from Orlando bio and bibliographical data is 5M triples, so that would become 20M.
If one wants to hang on to simple triple as well, one ends up with redundant data and you have to keep the two in sync with each other, because there is no way to keep a connection between simple triple and the reified version – this is risky for updates when dealing with dynamic datasets such as those CWRC is generating in which the data will grow and change over time.
The specificity of subject, object, and predicate are buried: they become classed individuals, with a consequent reduction in the logical operations that can be performed on the data (Hernandez 2015; Stevens 2010). For instance defining inverse properties (cause of death vs. cause of death of) becomes more onerous (W3C “n-ary relations”).

Finally, reification has not become a widely adopted solution. It is hardly mentioned in recent discussions and specifications. Even Wikidata, which appears to reify, is not doing that exactly: it simply uses a more complex data model than triples under the hood and exposes data in reified form (Erxleben 2014). The solution adopted overall seems to have been to move to named property graphs (which are not as standardized), quads, or schema-based ontologies (DuCharme, 2018).

Quads offer one alternative: most “triple-stores” usually have a fourth term, usually used for a name graph. One could have a separate graph for each triple, essentially putting an identifier on each triple that can be used in turn as the subject or object of other triples. However, at present, because CWRC hosts multiple projects that will be creating data for different purposes, on different time frames, etc. we plan to retain the fourth term for keeping sets of triples together so when we have a bunch of different datasets within a single LOD store users can easily query the one(s) they want. Therefore, we explored the possibilities associated with the Web Annotation data model.

The Web Annotation data model is a W3C recommendation as of 2017 that came in part out of DH community through the Open Annotation Project. Annotations are defined thus:
Annotations are typically used to convey information about a resource or associations between resources. Simple examples include a comment or tag on a single web page or image, or a blog post about a news article.
"The Web Annotation Data Model specification describes a structured model and format to enable annotations to be shared and reused across different hardware and software platforms. Common use cases can be modeled in a manner that is simple and convenient, while at the same time enabling more complex requirements, including linking arbitrary content to a particular data point or to segments of timed multimedia resources. "
The basic concept of the web annotation is simple, in that it creates a relationship between an object (the target of the annotation) and the content that annotates it (the body of the annotation).

CWRC is interested in Web Annotation data model for other reasons—much CWRC RDF will take the form of simple annotations of other documents, so building on Web Annotations made sense as a means of avoiding classic reification. Here below is a diagram of a web annotation identifying the person entity L.E.L. within an excerpt or snippet from the Orlando Project’s published textbase.

How, then, to relate the L.E.L.’s properties, such as her cause of death, to a Web Annotation? Simply adding relating the cause of death to L.E.L. herself would create no link to the description of her death in the excerpt.
We considered incorporating the cause of death into the annotation as a separate body in the annotation alongside L.E.L., since the model accommodates multiple bodies.

However, the triple can’t be included as actual RDF but only as a string or literal; this string would need to be processed separately from the other data. The result is that reading, extraction, reasoning etc. would all be vastly more complicated. As a result we almost went for reification.

However, given the disadvantages--including that all one would see in a standard graph visualization would be tons of “statements” with a generic subject-predicate-object structure, hardly elucidating--we decided to look harder at whether a schema-based model as advocated by Bob DuCharme could work. The cost, however, was that we ended up abandoning straightforward subject-centric triples, in which the subject is a person, in much of the way our data is modelled, in favour of what we call annotation- or context-centric triples, since the annotation or context is the central node in the cluster of relationships. However, building on the Web Annotation model get us the kinds of benefits we were looking for from reification without requiring it, and providing the advantages of using a standard structure with explicit semantics that will be interoperable with other Web Annotation data.

The CWRC approach to representing our data starts with the basic Web Annotation structure. We class annotations by Context, and although we keep identifying annotations for standard links to entities, we shift the motivation of the annotation when it comes to properties such as cause of death to describing, since these Annotations are about what the text is saying.

All the relationships are present here, but in “Context-centric” rather than a subject-centric way. What we think of intuitively as the “Subject” of the cause of death triple is there but is structurally an object: LEL, however, has a special, CWRC-defined relationship to the Annotation as the “contextFocus”, which is to say the subject of this particular Context. The “contextFocus” property, like other cwrc-defined properties linked to the annotations, becomes a sub-property of the standard oa:hasBody property. Links to source document from which the RDF was extracted are there, and so is certainty, and so will be citation links, and other information about this complex assertion. This graph is not as intuitively human-readable, but allows us to retain key contextualizing information that we consider key to creating robust humanities LODsets.

The Context-centric model does allow for subject-centric triples, but these would need to be generated from the source data--and the CWRC ontology is being constructed to provide both context-centric and subject-centric versions of predicates (for instance, causeOfDeath and hasCauseOfDeath, respectively), so that this could be done as a batch to create a derivative dataset or through the SPARQL Construct commands when running queries. The result provides the ability to use simple triples to explore basic assertional relationships, but provenance and context are there when needed. Moreover, the relationship between two different contextualized assertions provides means of dealing with contradictory data through an OR relation that allows both Contexts to exist even though two assertions associated with them logically cannot both be true – as in the case of assertions about L.E.L.’s cause of death being murder or suicide. In this case the low certainty value could be generated based on this contradiction in the data. This model thus provides support for reasoning that will help us to locate inaccuracies in our data, and it will also help to highlight areas of controversy, edge cases, differences across datasets, cases of negation or contradiction as something other than noise or dirt to be weeded out of the data, but rather as things that we as humanists frequently want to zero in on and examine more closely. That is, although it is certainly more complex than we thought our data would need to be when we embarked on the ontology design, we think this solution provides a model within which we can not only accommodate but actually interrogate and mobilize the messiness and diversity, which is to say the richness, of humanities data.

div.head: Works Cited

listBibl.bibl: DuCharme 2018. “Reification is a red herring” bobdc.com/blog. 22 April 2018.
CWRC 2018. CWRC Ontology Team. Canadian Writing Research Collaboratory Ontology. 2018.

div.bibl: Erxleben 2014. Erxleben, Fredo, Michael Günther, Markus Krötzsch, Julian Mendez, and Denny Vrandeci. “Introducing Wikidata to the Linked Data Web.” International Semantic Web Conference. Springer, Cham, 2014.
Hernández 2015. Hernández, D., Hogan, A. and Krötzsch, M.. “Reifying RDF: What works well with Wikidata?” SSWS@ISWC, 1457, pp.32-47.
Stevens 2010. Stevens Robert, and Phillip Lord. 2010. “Reification of Properties in an Ontology.” Ontogenesis.
W3C 2006. W3C Ontology Engineering and Patterns Task Force of the Semantic Web Best Practices and Deployment Working Group. “Defining N-ary Relations on the Semantic Web.” 2006.
W3C 2017. W3C Web Annotation Data Model. 23 February 2017.
